author: Seo Vania

text: +Abus Bambus Except the GBA doesn't hava a sound chip. It retains the GBC sound processor but everything else is made by the main CPU itself :). It's quite an hybrid system, so everything depends on how much CPU time and ROM space (for the samples) the developers wanted to reserve for the sound.

author: Atstyle

text: @Atstyle Except there was rather little else to explore but your next destination, since you were going to the places you just explored anyway. You couldn't work around the point of return after the Eclipse either, which was Port Rago,Te Ryu, Kolima Forest, the Bilibin Gate, and etc. If Dark Dawn had more exploration than another game, I won't waste my time playing it because imo, there was very little exploring. What was the point of putting Iris in the game if you couldn't use her?
author: XfishX

text: @XfishX well thats a bit too much here. it's your responsability to take your time and explore, which I did in this game as much as in the other ones. as soon as they tell me to go somewhere i do the opposite and explore every places except the "next destination". dark dawn had more explorinf than broken seal but a bit lesser than lost age. and yes the point of no return were not that bad xcept for the 1st one that can't be worked around.

text: @bonitachika792 3rd one wasn' that much easier... you simply have gained alot more experiences playing the 1st two game. author: malkav616

text: @malkav616 The new game is... both good and bad. It isn't horrible, but it doesn't compare to Golden Sun and The Lost Age by any means. Considering they had almost 10 years between the games, the new one should have been blow-your-mind amazing, but it wasn't. The biggest issues with me in the game were that there's points of no return, and you get relatively little exploring time; the game tells you where to go next instead of letting you figure it out... I'd still recommend it to anyone though.

author: lightignakelloyd

text: @lightignakelloyd You may like HAVING them, but you didn't like GETTING them. That's a BIG difference. You didn't like spending hours doing the same draw command over and over again. You didn't, you know you didn't, don't even try saying you did. You're acting like an invalid. FF8 is one of the worst games, but it still had a solid story, soundtrack, characters, ect. which made up for its terrible systems, but didn't save it.
author: genesisSOC

text: @genesisSOC i have 100 cures, 100 firas fires and stuff, i love it i have a collector spirit, or are you implying that I'm too stupid and that's the reaso i like it? are you suggesting that I'm anormal? because you know my friend, that you're starting to irk me, with you "no one liked that, it ruined it", keep this in your mind, I liked it, okay? I did, and I'll always do, if what you say would have been true in any dimension, FF8 would have been named as the worst game ever, which is not.
author: lightignakelloyd

text: @lightignakelloyd I don't think anyone likes sitting in the same battle for over 10+ minutes doing the same command over and over again drawing magic. Squall's turn, Draw, Stock Cure. Do that over and over and over until you have 100 Cures. Squall's turn, Draw, Stock Thunder. Do that over and over and over again until you have 100 Thunders. That's not some opinion, it's a fact. No one liked that. No one has ever liked that. No one ever will. It ruined the game completely.
author: genesisSOC

text: @genesisSOC that's your opinion, i respect it 150%, however, it's still your opinion, and not a fact, personally i liked it, and if it doesn't work for you, it's your problem, not the game, because the game is always the same, people just receive it and feel it in many different ways, goor or bad, and also, how can it ruin the game, if you took away  something from ff8 or any game in the world, then ff8 or whatever game it is dies instantly, and this is also applied to any mechanism in any game
author: lightignakelloyd

text: @lightignakelloyd The main meaning, what it's intended to be on paper, and what it actually is/how it actually works, in practice, are two completely different things. It was a new and cool idea on paper and was intended to make managing your characters and magic/summons easier and different, but in practice, it was a total fail and completely ruined the game in every single way.
author: genesisSOC

text: @genesisSOC i grabbed the main meaning of the system, linking yourself to a spiritual being in order to become stronger
author: lightignakelloyd

text: @lightignakelloyd In FF8, you had to spend hours and hours and hours drawing and stocking magic from each and every enemy, never to use it, but only to put it onto your stats. In Golden Sun, you just put the same elemental Djinn you found onto their respected character and learned new magic as you naturally leveled up, without having to spend hour drawing and stocking it from every monster, and could use it freely like in any other, good and proper, RPG. That is far from similar in every aspect.
author: genesisSOC

text: @genesisSOC how can FF8 be bad because of the junction system if Golden Sun djinn' system is so similar to it?? c'mon, i'm not saying they're one of a kind, but they're very similar, IMHO
author: lightignakelloyd

text: @Lancealot180 Role Playing Game lol! But the first two Golden Sun games would have made great rocket propelled grenades, because the enemy would stop attacking and play them xD

text:
@PleaseDieQuietly I absolutely love Golden Sun. I got it as soon as it came out and I played it from glorious start to oh so satisfying ending.

That being said, no. Golden Sun does not compare to Final Fantasy. Golden Sun is not better than Omnislashing Sephiroth, Kefka destroying the world, or Kuja casting Ultima. Golden Sun, however, is better than Lost Odyssey or Fable. By far. Golden Sun is definitely a great game. But sadly, not as good as my personal favorite top 10.

text: Gotta agree, this game has an awesome soundtrack
author: Jean-Christophe Lavoie

text:
Music these days is all just ambient loops with no actual melody

Everyone is to busy focusing on "atmosphere" rather than actual musical substance.  It's really too bad.
author: steakspice

text:
I´ve never heard any other handheld music which could be compared to the wonderful music in GS2 (part 2 cause GS2 had that jukebox ingame with the music from part 1).
Seriously, why do the games of today not concentrate more on their music? For me, the background music makes 35% of the game, f.e. the music in GS2 expresses perfectly the atmosphere, drama. If you like this song you should also listen to that song in GS1 where you have to take that ship to cross the karagol sea to get to tolbi
